body.p:
Having a few minutes leisure before
synagogue I embrace it gladly to reply to your last which
for my inclination has remained too long unanswered. I regret
much that you did not order my article to be altered as I requested
you, since it will force me to continue the said article to a greater
length than agreeable to me. But as you say it was unavoidably so
I must be content. You are mistaken however if you think I don't
know what inconvenience it causes to alter a form. I have seen
a great deal of printing in my time and have corrected more than
one proof for the press. My dear Mr Leeser you must not again
write me “I am a little tired of a work that brings me nothing
but vexation” You are yet too young in your vocation to cry
with Solomon — מה יתרון לאדם בכל עמלו שיעמל תחת השמש nor can
you with any truth say with him וְהִנֵּה הַכֹּל הֶבֶל וּרְעוּת רוּחַ קהלת א, יד והנה הכל הבל ורעות רוח no such
thing, dear friend, you are appreciated if not by כל העדה, yet by
all those whose good ? is worth having. You, no doubt,
with me, think one roar of the lion more agreeable than 50 brays
of the jackass. And these roars of the lions (not of New York or
Richmond) you have. What more then do you want? Is it assistance,
look through your vol. 6, and see whether I have not done
my share. I never asked any other return than what you chose
to give me. Your favorable opinion was enough for me.
You are not a Saxon, don't be a grumbler then but continue
like a good boy at your task. If you continue to perform it as
properly as heretofore, the Sugarphim? shall not be long in coming

neglect it and expect to receive what we used to style in our
Hebrew school — palackas. I promise you that the first one
you get shall be from from the hand (if it be alive) that is now
perusing these words. So look out. Now I shall give you a little
more vexation in respect to the Occident à la Carondle?; A pretty Editor
you are Mr. I. I should like to know how you expect to keep
a subscriber when you send your numbers so irregularly. Here is the
half of April over and your Canadian subscribers have not yet
received either their March or April numbers. Pretty ? truly.
I guess your news will be pretty stale to them, And then the
circular that was to go with them, why how can we know what's
going on. The Proposed assembly may be no longer a proposed assembly
but have already taken place to and we poor unfortunate neglected
and abandoned creatures know nothing of it If this isn't enough
to make a person swear I don't know what is. Take care
your eyes for if they get near my nails Mr I I don't know
what the consequences might not be — but really you
must be a little more regular in sending them i.e. in getting
your agent in New York to do so, for I hear it is his fault.
It is doubly disagreeable for a correspondent to receive them so
late as there might be some Er? to be made in his
article which he would like to send forth next number.
I shall say no more about it now because I hope that you
will take steps to let us have them in future by the 6th or 7th of
the month. I shall write to England the? endeavor to press the
sale of these. I don't think you have a good agent in Mrs Joel
She lives in F? Street which is entirely out of the world
and especially out of the Jewish world. I think Sam'
Solomons of Bevis Marks would be able to push the sale

better. Did you ever try him? Not having received the March
Occident I have not seen the circular. As soon as received I shall
call a meeting of the congregation and we will doubtless not be
needful. I am a little vext at the delay of the Occident this ?
There is no other congregation in Canada but the ? in Montreal
and the German one that formerly existed is on its last legs. They
were but a poor and troublesome set who lately composed it
neither ornamental nor useful in a synagogue above all in a
Portuguese synagogue the פסוך of which they “?.”
As for my long being inclined to support the assembly without
being able to say ? with Dr. Cantwell I can lead the
poor deluded men where I please” I think I shall be able to
induce within them a favourable opinion on these matters.
If you don't go to New Orleans I shall expect you in Canada
this summer. Let me know whether you come and I will
prepare a room for you in my house which is next door
to Mrs Josephs. Mr and Mrs JHJ and Miss Sarah J start
Sunday, I believe for the States. Is it true that Nathan
has given up his situation in St. Thomas and is now in New
Orleans with Carillon? also. That this letter worthy who
is required by all as a madman should care to look for
another nest, I am not at all surprised for he has made the
West Indies “too hot to hold him” but Mr. Nathan what
does he run about for. I can't help thinking that it is
a great pity he ever gave up his situation in Kingston. I
sincerely hope that those congregations wanting a Hazan in
the States will be especially carefully of Carillon?. He has
? discord wherever he has been — and will continue to
do so wherever he goes. And then his principles, as accomodating

as the weather cock to every puff of wind. I hope that you
will keep your eye upon him, and look to the interests
of our cause. You will understand me. I never saw Carillon
in my life have never corresponded with him but what I do
know of him as a Rabbi and Teacher I can't admire. And more
I ask you keep your eye on him. With respect to the situation
at Richmond I have written to Mr. Hyman for farther particulars but
I confess more with the intention of ascertaining whether the situation
as worthy the acceptance of my brother in law Hazan Mendes
of Montego Bay. He is a most worthy & talented young man, a gentleman
and scholar and quite orthodox. I would like him to be near me
I did not mention names to Mr. Hyman nor does Mr Mendes know
that I have written. I need scarcely tell you then that the name
is to continue שמחת יום טוב. I am glad to see that I have not been too severe
in forming my estimate of the attainments of Mr Lyons of New York
I agree with you in considering that the (his brother I dont know
is not one who ought to be at the head of a Congregation in the
present state of things. His surprising land? I say with all my
heart, most lamentable that with such a field before him he has
not done more to make our religion more respectable among his
flock. I asked you to insert my sermon in your ? because it would have
been read with more interest with the Passover but do with
it what you please. It is not so formidable thing to write a sermon
Having now replied to your letter in full I shall send you one or two
news items if indeed you have not already received them.
I expected? writing you more fully but I must break off
I milk will write by Mr Joseph wishing you all blessings and prosperity
